citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
A 5-year-old female pig was observed to have scaly, thickened skin with brown scabs encompassing both ears as well as
pinkish-red skin behind both ears, near her neck that was not being treated per the attending veterinarian’s guidance. The
pig has lighter skin and the licensee stated that it was a sunburn that she gets every year, therefore she didn't feel it was
necessary to contact the attending veterinarian.
The licensee had observed the skin issue but not followed up with the veterinarian for evaluation, diagnosis and treatment
recommendations. Failing to notify the veterinarian of medical concerns delays treatment that can be detrimental to the
animal’s health and well-being.
The licensee must consult with the attending veterinarian to obtain a treatment plan for this pig and then, moving forward,
in cooperation with her attending veterinarian, the licensee must develop appropriate methods to prevent, control,
diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries.
Corrected during inspection.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by AUGUST 12, 2023 or the applicant will forfeit the license
fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
n
